1:
CAS-14(10)/DogSquad/BDDS/2010 
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY  
(MINISTRY OF CIVIL AVIATION) 
GOVERNMENT OF INDIA 
‘A’ WING, JANPATH BHAWAN 
JANPATH, NEW DELHI- 110001 
Dated :      06 /01/2011 
 
Circular No  01/2011 
 
 
Subject :-  SOP ON MANAGEMENT OF DOG SQUADS FOR CIVIL AVIATION        
SECURITY AT AIRPORTS WHERE CISF IS DEPLOYED 
 
 
 
 
 
The guidelines are based on the standard practices being adopted for 
management of dog squads by different organizations.  However, the instructions may be 
suitably adapted to suit local conditions. Efforts have been made to make the guidelines 
comprehensive but certain aspects still need proper planning and thinking.  
Supplementary guidelines shall be issued in due course when changes become 
imperative due to development of new technology and material. 
 
 
Use of IEDs as a low cost-high impact option to create terror and incapacitate the 
security forces has emerged as the general modus operandi of terrorists. Frequent 
casualties due to such blasts have become a major cause of concern for all. The counter 
IED equipment profile offers technological solutions but they have their limitations. Dogs 
provide a viable and effective alternative to technology. Sniffer dogs, due to their natural 
sniffing capabilities, have been successful in detection of explosives. 
 
 
However, dog is to be used in a professional manner and nurtured well for 
optimum results. Hence, everybody has to understand varied aspects of dog care and 
maintenance and at the same time provide interface to the force through good ‘Dog 
Handlers’. Thus, ‘Dog Squad’ as a whole, consisting of the dog and his handler has to be 
adequately taken care of. Dog Handler should first know his dog and then understand the 
intricacies of ‘operational environment’ so that the use of dog can be made in best 
possible way for desired end results. 
 
 
Hence, keeping the above issues in mind, these guidelines and instructions have 
been framed and compiled for the information of everyone involved with the working of 
the dog squad to enable them to make the best use of the dog squad as an instrument of 
security and for preventing loss of life and property. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
(Gurjot Singh Malhi, IPS) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Commissioner of Security (CA)
2:
INTRODUCTION :- 
 
1. 
Dogs due to their certain inherent qualities have become an integral and extremely 
useful tool for the security forces in modern times.  It is known for its extraordinary power 
of sniffing which is almost 100 times that of humans, ultrasonic hearing, natural night 
vision capability and readiness to work under all geo-climatic conditions. It is aggressive, 
alert, loyal, relatively inexpensive and easy to train. 
 
2. 
To prevent sabotage activities leading to unlawful interference with Civil Aviation 
Operations, by means of placing an explosive device, explosive substances or other such 
material in the aircraft, operational area of the airport, terminal building or any other such 
place at the airport directly connected with the Civil Aviation Operations or carriage of 
explosive, explosive device, explosive substances in hand baggage, registered baggage, 
cargo, mails catering items, company stores without prior permission of the competent 
authority, it is essential to check the above areas, sites, equipments, items etc to detect 
explosive and explosive substance whenever considered necessary. Following yardsticks 
have been followed while working out requirement of Dogs, Dog Handlers and Kennel-
men for the various Dog Squads being deployed :- 
 
 
(i) 
Dog Squad is an integral part of the Bomb Detection and Disposal Squads 
 
(BDDS) and will only move “On Call”. 
 
 
(ii) 
Each ED team will have 02 Dogs. In addition, separate dogs will be 
 
earmarked for patrolling and surveillance purposes. 
 
 
(iii) 
The random checks will be of maximum 4 hours in which after every half 
 
hour, rest of 10 minutes will be given to the dogs. The dogs will work in tandem to 
 
each other. 
 
 
(iv) 
After each duty of 4 hours, 24 hours rest will be given to dogs.  
 
 
 
(v) 
One Kennel-man per 5 Dogs will be the scale of authorization of Kennel-
 
man. 
 
 
(vi) 
Each dog will have a dedicated Dog Handler. In addition, reserves  have 
 
also been catered for. 
 
 
 
(vii) 
Airport operator concerned will be responsible for all administrative issues 
 
concerning the Dog Squad. 
 
 
(vii) 
No additional dogs have been catered for patrolling purposes at airports 
 
where there is only one operational shift.
3:
-2- 
 
BREEDS OF DOGS :- 
 
3. 
It is recommended that Labrador Retriever, Golden Retriever and Cocker Spaniel 
be the standard dogs for Dog Squads as they have proven to be the most reliable for ED 
duties in Indian conditions. 
 
4. 
The following guidelines shall be borne in mind in selecting and procuring the dogs 
for Dog Squads:- 
 
 
(a) 
Pedigree: If possible have a look at the sire as well as the dame.  Do not 
 
merely go by a certificate. 
 
 
(b) 
Preferably male dogs should be procured. 
 
 
(c) 
Buy pups of 3-6 months age only and not a grown up dog. 
 
 
(d) 
Observe a pup from a distance without disturbing it preferably in whelping 
 
area,  to observe its movement and reaction to your approach. An intelligent pup 
 
will give a definite reaction to your approach. 
 
 
(e) 
A sound pup should have well developed and proportioned body, with 
 
well-developed bone, strong back, shiny coat, deep chest and muscular feet 
 
with well-cushioned foot pad. 
 
 
(f) 
All limbs should be sturdy, well formed and graceful. 
 
 
(g) 
Look out for faults such as bend in feet, poor shoulder placement, lack of 
 
co-ordination in limbs or a body configuration. 
 
 
(h) 
Do not select pups with running nose and eyes.  It may indicate distemper 
 
disease. Keep such pups under observation for a month before they are 
 
purchased. 
 
 
(i) 
A Pup with enlarged tummy is generally suffering from malnutrition or from 
 
poorly managed kennels. 
 
 
(j) 
Examine its mouth for overshot/undershot jaw. 
 
 
(k) 
Coat should be shining and free from rashes. Harsh and dull skin indicates 
 
poor health as well as skin ailment. 
 
 
(l) 
Eyes should be clear and bright. The nose and mouth should be according 
 
to breed specifications. 
 
 
(m) 
Ears should be clean and odourless. 
 
 
(n) 
The Pup should give an impression of being vigorous, sensitive, 
 
intelligent, energetic, aggressive and not timid or excitable.
4:
-3- 
 
 
COMPOSITION OF DOG SQUAD :- 
 
5. 
Each Dog Squad shall consist of One SI (as in-charge of Dog Squad), Dog 
Handler, Kennel man and Dogs. Deployment schedule for each airport has been attached 
as Appendix ‘A’. A Dog Squad is an integral part of Bomb Detection and Disposal Team. 
Each ED team will comprise of 02 Dogs who will work in tandem. The ED team is 
deployed only “On Call” and routine random check which should not be more than           
4 hours.  These dogs will not perform routine patrolling duties. In addition, each Dog 
Squad will have dedicated dogs for patrolling and surveillance @ 1dog per shift at each 
airport.  
 
6. 
History sheet of each dog shall be prepared by the Sub Inspector In-charge  of 
Dog Squad clearly mentioning the following details which will be checked and signed by 
the competent authority :- 
 
 
(a) 
Pedigree (Name of sire and dame, KCI-Registration No and procured from 
 
any registered Kennel club). 
 
 
 
(b) 
Sex 
 
 
(c) 
Date of Birth 
 
 
(d) 
Colour of Coat 
 
 
(e) 
Colour of eyes 
 
 
(f) 
Shape of ears 
 
 
(g) 
Identification marks 
 
 
(h) 
Height, length and weigh on date of birth/purchase. 
 
 
(i) 
Source of acquisition with full address of previous owner. 
 
 
(j) 
ARV/DHL/PARVO record, dates and doses given. 
 
 
(k) 
Name and address of the present owner. 
 
 
 
(l) 
Number/name of the dog.

TRAINING :- 
 
9. 
Developing Dog – Handler relations with the Dog in an important aspect of training. 
It shall aim at developing emotional bonding ,nurturing affectionate and cordial relation 
between the dog and the handler.  It has to be a caring relationship, akin to a parent-child 
bonding.  Cost of training of dog will be borne by the airport operator concerned. 
 
10. 
Principles of Dog Training:- 
 
 
(a) 
Kindness/firmness. 
 
 
(b) 
Repetition. 
 
 
(c) 
Correction. 
 
 
(d) 
Determination. 
 
 
(e) 
Time & Mind. 
 
 
(f) 
Reward & Punishment. 
 
 
(g) 
Successful. 
 
 
(h) 
Tone. 
 
11. 
The handler shall:- 
 
 
(a) 
Reward for a good response. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Gently correct deficiencies. 
 
 
(c) 
Selectively use food as an incentive to motivate the dog. 
 
 
(d) 
Avoid physical and verbal punishment. 
 
 
12. 
Revalidation of training, including practical exercises along with the annual training 
of the handler to the extent necessary and feasible should be ensured. 
 
 
13. 
Training should include the following:- 
 
 
(a) 
Physical fitness (with the help of daily exercises). 
 
 
(b) 
Reviving sniffing power (with the help of sniffing exercise). 
 
 
 
(c) 
Basic obedience exercise (for better command and control). 
 
 
(d) 
Improvement of reflexes (through balls, toys and other artificial aids). 
 
 
(e) 
Operational efficiency (through simulated exercises).

(a)

(b)

(c) 
Ensure daily brushing of dog’s teeth. 
 
 
 
(d)

(e)

separately. 
 
 
(f) 
Cut angled nails using nail clipper.
8:
-7- 
 
16. 
Daily Operation Drills shall include:- 
 
 
 
 
(a) 
Refresh his sniffing power through explosive samples. Standard list of 
explosives for training is given at Paragraph 24 which should be procured and kept 
by each Dog Squad. 
 
 
(b) 
Undertake simulated exercise to detect different explosives being used by 
 
terrorist groups in the country.  
 
 
(c) 
Make him undergo warm up exercises to enhance his stamina in the form 
 
of jumping, running, sniffing etc. 
 
 
(d) 
Subject him to special movements like crawling, rolling, side movements 
 
etc. 
 
 
 
(e) 
Pat the dog after it has successfully performed a task/exercise. 
 
17. 
GROOMING OF DOGS 
 
 
The actual cleaning of the coat and skin is done with the help of brush and steel 
comb.  First, the dog is given a vigorous massage with the tip of the fingers.  This brings 
out the hidden dust, loosens the broken hair and stimulates the blood circulation of the 
skin.  Then the coat is brushed with a body brush in a circular manner and then in the 
direction of the hair.  After this a steel comb is used to remove the dead and tangled hair. 
Comb is also useful in untangling the matted hair. Finally, the dogs are massaged 
vigorously with the flat of the palm to give a shiny and glossy appearance.  This also sets 
the hair.  During the grooming period, following organs are attended to as follows:- 
 
 
(a) 
Eyes:- 
Discharge, when present, should be removed with clean         
 
cotton soaked in warm water. Eye lotions, unless specifically prescribed by a 
 
veterinary officer, should not be used.  If any symptoms of infection or injury are 
 
noted, for example weeping or opacity, the dog must be taken for examination and 
 
treated by a veterinary doctor. 
 
 
(b) 
Teeth:- 
Normally the teeth of the dog require very little attention.  
 
Discoloured or stained teeth may be cleaned with a weak solution of hydrogen 
 
peroxide once a month.  Should the accumulation of tartar be excessive, it may be 
 
necessary to scale them from time to time. 
 
 
(c) 
Ears :- 
The daily inspection and cleaning of the ears is most 
 
important.  The accumulation of wax and dirt can, especially in long eared dogs, 
 
cause severe inflammation and  irritation.  Wax and dirt are best removed with the 
 
aid of cotton wool, either dry or soaked in warm water.  Although the eardrum of a 
 
dog is well protected from injury, care should be taken when cleaning deep down 
 
in the ear canal as this can cause considerable discomfort to the dog.
9:
-8- 
 
 
(d) 
Nails :- 
With regular exercise, nails requires little attention.  However, 
 
they must be watched for over growth. Overgrown nails must be trimmed, as, if 
 
left, they will split and cause lameness. Only a properly trained person should do 
 
trimming, as excessive cutting will produce lameness. The dewclaws (rudimentary 
 
first digit) serve no useful purpose and can be removed surgically by a veterinary 
 
surgeon. 
 
 
(e) 
Anus :- 
Regular inspection of the anal sphincter is required to see if 
 
any segments of tapeworms are sticking or protruding.  Regular watch is also kept 
 
to see if anal glands are impacted. The anal sphincter and anal glands 
 
lubricate the passage of stool. The anal glands are normally prevented from 
 
getting impacted by the process of defecation. However, if they are impacted, a 
 
piece of cotton wool is placed over the anus and firm pressure is applied with the 
 
fore finger and thumb which relieves the impaction. 
 
18. 
BENEFITS OF GROOMING :- 
 
 
(a) 
Hidden wounds are exposed. 
 
 
(b) 
Ticks/fleas can be removed. 
 
 
(c) 
Increases the blood circulation. 
 
 
(d) 
Minimizes fatigue. 
 
 
(e) 
Enhances coat quality. 
 
 
(f) 
Loose hair is shed off. 
 
 
(g) 
Dog looks attractive. 
 
 
(h) 
Increases the affection between dog and handler. 
 
19. 
TICK CONTROL:- 
 
 
(a) 
Being transmitters of piroplasmosis, control of ticks is of vital  importance. 
 
Ticks are blood-sucking parasites, which attach themselves to the skin for varying 
 
period of time. If numerous they can be very irritating to the dog causing 
 
restlessness and subsequent loss of concentration. Heavy infestation may 
 
also result in anemia. 
 
 
(b) 
During grooming and on dogs return from exercise, dogs should be 
 
thoroughly “de-ticked”. Ticks are most frequently found around the head, 
 
especially in the ears, the fold of the earflap, between the toes and to a lesser 
 
degree on other parts of the body.  Great care must be exercised in their removal, 
 
if roughly pulled, the head may remain embedded in the skin with results in 
 
abscess formation. They are best removed with help of forceps. However, with 
 
care and practice they can be removed quite efficiently with the fore finger and 
 
thumb.  Once removed, they should be placed in a container containing kerosene 
 
and burnt when the operation is completed.
10:
-9- 
 
 
(c) 
All vegetation within 3 to 4 meters of the kennel must be cleaned by 
 
burning. In areas where fire risk exists , liquid insecticides can be  sprayed on the 
 
vegetation .The kennels themselves must be regularly disinfected with particular 
 
attention being paid to crevices and cracks in the concrete floor and walls.  
 
Blowlamp is  found to be of good value in dealing with these sites. 
 
20. 
BATHING :- 
 
 
(a) 
A dog should be bathed as infrequently as possible. 
 
 
(b) 
The skin of the dog is rich in grease glands.  Frequent bathing removes this 
 
natural grease resulting in dry skin with accompanying irritation and also gives a 
 
harsh appearance. 
 
 
(c) 
If it is necessary to bathe a dog, warm, but not hot water should be 
 
used; the temperature should not exceed 1000 F.  Care must be taken to prevent 
 
soap and water from entering the eyes and ears.  This can be avoided by plugging 
 
ears  with cotton wool. As the skin of the dog is very sensitive, only bland soaps 
 
should be used. Carbolic soaps, if applied direct to the body, cause severe 
 
irritation. After the dog has been  washed, the coat must be thoroughly rinsed 
 
to remove all traces of soap and dried with towel. 
 
21. 
CLIPPING :- 
 
 
 
Clipping of hair is never practiced in a Dog except where recommended by  
 
a veterinary officer. However, trimming of hair of heavy coated dog may be 
 
practiced during summer. 
 
22. 
HANDLING AND RESTRAINT 
 
An ailing or injured dog is apt to bite anyone handling it, either because it is in pain, 
is afraid or not fully aware of its actions. For this reason, care must be  
taken in 
handling and the animal must be restrained to prevent it from biting.  The  dog 
should be approached and handled calmly, confidently, quietly, firmly and 
deliberately but with sympathy and understanding.  It is usually preferable to allow 
the dog to see one approaching and to let it realize that; the leash being kept 
sufficiently tight to prevent the dog from running away.  The dog should  
then be 
muzzled, or its mouth should be taped, while the assistant holds the head. To         
‘tape’  a dog, a piece of bandage, or other material, about three feet long and three 
inches wide, is required.  Make an ordinary single loop in the middle of the 
bandage and slip this loop over the muzzle with the twist on upper side. Pull this 
tight enough to prevent the dog from opening its mouth, cross the bandage below 
the jaw, and then carry the ends below the ears and tie at the back of the neck.  If 
the dog is inclined  to slip the loop, it may be slipped over the muzzle while 
holding the bandage so that the hands are safe.  If the dog is behaving awkwardly, 
a strong handler should seize it by the scruff of the neck, with one hand on each 
side, and place the dogs body between his legs. The animal can then be firmly 
held and muzzled or taped.
11:
-10- 
 
23. 
ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN WHEN THE DOG SUSTAINS INJURY OR BECOMES 
 
EXHAUSTED 
 
 
(a) 
Stop further progress/movement of the dog. Carry it to shade/shelter and 
 
keep the dog in complete rest and check the temperature. Offer water with 
 
electoral/glucose powder. Put a tourniquet in proximity to the wound in case of 
 
severe bleeding and apply antiseptic ointment/powder after cleaning the wound 
 
and applying tincture benzene to arrest bleeding. Then, put on a bandage with 
 
sufficient cotton padding. 
 
 
(b) 
In case of fractures, the affected portion may be immobilized by tying splints 
 
over cotton/cloth padding and then the animal may be evacuated by fastest 
 
possible means to nearest Veterinary Hospital for necessary treatment. 
 
 
(c) 
In case of snakebite, a tourniquet may be applied in proximity to the wound 
 
immediately and sufficient pressure should be applied for proper bleeding and 
 
washing out of the poison. The wound may be washed with soap and flushed with 
 
large quantity of water and antibiotic cream should be applied later. 
 
 
(d) 
After sustaining an injury/during sickness, the  animal should not be allowed 
 
to walk; it may either be carried in arms or in stretcher, which can be easily made 
 
by two poles tied on both sides of ground sheet/durries IT. 
 
 
(e) 
In case of gun shot wounds, action may be taken as mentioned above as 
 
the animal may be immobile. In case of fracture, gun shot wounds or severe 
 
injuries, Morphine/Pethidine can be given, to keep the animal quiet and free from 
 
pain. 
 
 
(f) 
In case of heat stroke and dehydration, the dog may be carried to shade 
 
and given sufficient drinking water.  If the body temperature is very high, cold water 
 
may be poured over the body or cloth dipped in cold water may be wrapped 
 
around the animal.  The dog must be given complete rest and permitted to drink as 
 
much water as it can in frequent intervals during evacuation. 
 
 
(g) 
In case of sprain/contusion, the affected part may be cooled by pouring cold 
 
water/wrapping in cloth dipped in cold water and kept immobilized. 
 
 
(h) 
When the dogs are given full feed, at least half an hour rest may be given 
 
before proceeding on employment.  If time does not permit, they may be  fed only 
 
light feed, which may be repeated as required. As far as possible, heavy  feeding 
 
should not be done during the duty and sudden diet may be avoided to prevent 
 
sickness.

SCHEDULE OF DOG WHEN BEING TAKEN OUT FOR DUTY :- 
 
25. 
Before taking the dog out:- 
 
 
(a) 
Ensure daily checkup, exercise, operational drills and general response. 
 
 
(b) 
Ensure carriage of  diet supplements, clothes, portable bedding, first aid kit 
 
and other required accessories as per the length of the deployment. 
 
 
(c) 
Warm up the dog before proceeding on duty. 
 
 
(d) 
Stay with the dog and encourage him regularly.
13:
-12- 
 
26. 
During Work:- 
 
 
(a) 
Earmark his position with the ED Team. 
 
 
(b) 
10 minutes rest to be ensured after every 30 minutes of duty. 
 
 
(c) 
Maximum 4 hours duty in a day should be performed. 
 
 
 
(d) 
Provide water and light feed in between as per need. 
 
 
(e) 
Observe body language and behavior closely. 
 
 
(f) 
Keep him secure during operations. 
 
27. 
On Return :- 
 
 
(a) 
Check his general health and ensure cleaning, medical care etc. 
 
 
(b) 
Provide appropriate rest. 
 
 
(c) 
Give incentive by way of items liked by the dog in case he succeeds in 
 
an operation but be very selective. 
 
 
(d) 
Record his performance and behavior. 
 
 
(e) 
Ensure 24 hrs rest after 4 hours of duty. 
 
MOBILITY AND TRANSPORT:- 
 
28. 
For short distance movement on foot, dog should be properly chained and 
accompanied with the handler. 
 
29. 
For short distance movement on vehicle, dog can be taken along with the ED team 
in the same vehicle but kept at a safe place. 
 
30. 
Do not feed a dog immediately before travelling. 
 
31. 
Other precautions may be added in consultation with veterinary expert. 
 
HEALTH AND HYGIENE:- 
 
32. 
Diet  :- Proper diet is essential for maintaining dog’s health and for the 
management of many diseases. However, veterinary doctor can be consulted to decide 
on the composition of food as per local conditions and the health of the dog.  
General 
instructions regarding providing food to the dog is as under :- 
 
 
(a) 
Feeding and water bowl should be cleaned daily and kept at a permanent 
 
place. 
 
 
(b) 
Ensure that fresh water is made available to the dog for drinking.
14:
-13- 
 
 
(c) 
Meals should be fed fresh at room temperature. 
 
 
(d) 
Unconsumed food should be removed in 10-15 minutes after the dog 
 
finishes eating. 
 
 
(e) 
Sweet and salt should be avoided as they decrease the life span and 
 
causes skin problems. 
 
 
(f) 
Feeds should be given at the same time and place as far as possible. 
 
 
(g) 
Do not disturb the dog while eating. 
 
 
(h) 
Water bowl should be kept near the food bowl. 
 
 
(i) 
Dogs require two meals per day at the age of 1 year and above. 
 
 
(j) 
Generally, dogs get their required nutrition from regular meals. However, if 
 
required, he may be given a special diet occasionally between 04 to 05 PM i.e at 
 
least 03 hours prior to his regular meal as per the advice of veterinarian. 
 
 
(k) 
As per directions of veterinarian, on prolonged working by dogs, special 
 
diet supplement can be given in the form of Glucose mixed in water besides milk, 
 
egg etc but not on a regular basis.

15:

34. 
DE WORMING :- 
 
 
Step 1 :- 
Visit vet to get a prescribed de-worming medication.   
 
 
Step 2 :- 
Administer the first dose of medication when the puppy is 2 weeks 
 
old.  Give him the same medication again at 4, 6 and 8 weeks of age. This 
 
aggressive programme will kill anything still living inside the puppy. 
 
 
Step 3 :- 
Thereafter, administer the medication once per month. If the  puppy 
 
was 8 weeks old at the last treatment, then wait until he turns three  months old for 
 
the next dose. Do this again at months 4, 5 and 6. That will mark the end of de-
 
worming schedule. 
 
 
Step 4 :- 
Head back to vet to get a heartworm preventive medication  which is 
 
also effective against roundworms and hookworms. This medication is for 
 
maintenance purposes and will further protect the life of puppy. 
 
 
 
For adult dogs i.e 9 months and above, repeat de-worming after every 3 
 
months throughout life or as advised by your vet. 
 
 
Note :-  
Stool examination may be done after every three months and de -
 
worming to be ensured before vaccination. Medicines and dose should as per 
 
the prescription of the vet doctor or as prescribed on product literature. 
 
35. 
CLINICAL INFORMATION ON DOGS :- 
 
• Temperature  
 
 
- 
 38-39o C/100 to 101.5o F 
• Pulse rate 
 
 
 
- 
80 – 100 per minute 
• Respiration  
 
 
- 
20-30 beats per minute 
• Oestrus 
 
 
 
- 
21 days twice every year 
• Best day for service  
 
- 
9-13 days of oestrus 
• Duration of pregnancy 
 
- 
57-63 days 
• Age of maturity 
 
 
- 
Male 7-10 month, 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Females 6-12 months 
• ESR  
 
 
 
- 
5 to 20 mm /hour 
• PCV  
 
 
 
- 
30 to 40 mm/% 
• Hb 
 
 
 
 
- 
12 to 16 gms 
• BUN (Renal Function Test) 
- 
17 to 38 Mg/D1 
• Creatinine 
 
 
 
- 
1.0 to 1.7 mg/D1 
 
36. 
CHECKUP LIST FOR UNHEALTHY SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS IN DOGS:- 
 
 
(i) 
Overall General Check: 
 
 
Eyes  
Discharge of water, accumulation of dirt etc. 
 
 
Mouth  
Check teeth and gums for inflammation  
 
 
Nose  
Normally nose is cold and damp, dry and warm inside with no discharge.
16:
-15- 
 
 
Ears  
: Dirty, appearance of dark wax/redness, inflammation, change in angle, 
 
 
 
   lack of alertness. 
 
 
Coat  
: Lack of cleanliness and gloss, lose of hair, presence of dirt of parasites. 
 
 
Claws  
: Appearance of any splits, lack of trimming. 
 
 
Abdomen 
: Tapering away from back legs, sensitive to touch, tenderness. 
 
 
Breathing 
: Normally it is quite and even when at rest, panting when cooling down, 
 
 
 
  no coughing.  
 
 
Appetite 
: Slow eating, disinterest in food. 
 
 
Manners 
: Lack of alertness and quick response to sound and instructions. 
 
 
Movement 
: Uneven gait, uneven weight distribution over all four legs. 
 
 
Faeces 
: Irregular bowel motions, loose discharge (however it varies as per diet). 
 
 
 
Anus  
: Accumulation of mucus, clinging of any material. 
 
37. 
DAILY MINIMUM CHECKS : 
 
 
(a) 
Are its eyes bright and clean? Sore discharge or ulcers should not be  
 
present. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Is the nose clean ?  Slightly moist and free from crusty discharge? 
 
 
(c) 
Check dog’s mouth ? Gums should look pink, The teeth should not  be          
 
discoloured and there should be no foreign bodies or traces of food in the  mouth. 
 
 
(d) 
Are its ears clean and free of waxy discharge and odour ? 
 
 
(e) 
Check paws for cuts, abrasions and foreign bodies trapped between the 
 
toes? 
 
 
(f) 
It the dog scratching parts of its body? 
 
 
(g) 
Does the dog appear lame?  Check for changes in posture or a suitable 
 
alteration in its gait. 
 
 
(h) 
Does it have high temperature? 
 
38. 
MAIN DISEASES – SYMPTOMS AND CAUSES :- 
 
 
(i) 
Distemper (Infection Disease of Dogs): 
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS 
 
 
 
(a) 
Symptoms start within 02 weeks of infection. 
 
 
 
 
(b) 
Dog is dull, restless and lack of appetite is seen.
17:
-16- 
 
 
 
(c) 
High fever. 
 
 
 
 
(d) 
Further develops watery eyes, nasal discharge with pus and cough, 
 
black foul smelling motions. 
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
 
(a) 
Caused by air borne virus. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Virus contaminates the atmosphere. 
 
 
 
 
(c) 
Body contact not required for transmission of disease. 
 
 
(ii) 
Infectious Canine Hepatitis: More common in early life, disease affects 
the liver of the dogs.  
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS  
 
 
 
(a) 
Sudden rise in temperature. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Drowsiness, vomiting, feeling of thirst, loss of appetite, watery  
 
discharge from eyes and nose which thickens gradually and bloody 
 
diarrhea. 
 
 
 
(c) 
Sometimes swelling of the head, neck and abdomen. 
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
(a) 
Caused by virus. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Spread by contact with excretions like saliva, urine and faecal 
 
material. 
 
 
 
(iii) 
Leptospirosis 
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS  
 
 
 
(a) 
High fever, restlessness, refusal to eat, vomiting and dark coloured 
 
urine. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Reluctance to walk and if he does, he exhibits pain involving the 
 
posterior part of his body.  
 
 
 
(c) 
Palpitation of the abdomen, kidneys, some times jaundice is also 
 
noticed. 
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
(a) 
Caused by organism of genus leptospira. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Transmitted through contact with the excretion of infected animal
 
like urine (most important carrier).
18:
-17- 
 
 
 
(c) 
Also spread through mouth or nasal mucous membrane. 
 
 
(iv) 
Para Influenza :  Disease mainly affects the upper respiratory tract. 
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS  
 
 
 
(a) 
Mild fever and nasal discharge. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Irritation of lungs may cause persistent dry cough. 
 
 
 
(c) 
Disease if often complicated by secondary bacterial and other viral 
 
infection may cause pneumonia.  
 
 
 
(d) 
In complex form, disease is called kennel cough. 
 
 
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
(a) 
Caused by viral and spreads through the air. 
 
 
(v) 
Parvo Virus Disease: The most common disease in dogs.  It affects dogs 
of any age, breed and sex.  It especially affects young puppies less than 05 to 06 
months. Parvo virus is very tough and survives under very high and low 
temperatures.  
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS  
 
 
 
(a) 
Depression, difficulty in breathing and weakness. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Temperature is below normal, in some cases slight fever is also 
 
there. 
 
 
 
(c) 
Dullness, vomiting and diarrhea with or without blood.  
 
 
 
 
 
(d) 
Sometimes dehydration. 
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
(a) 
Caused by virus. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Spreads on contact through the hair and feet of the affected dogs 
 
(even  dog handler can carry a virus).  
 
 
 
(c) 
All excretion of dogs may carry the virus. 
 
 
 
(d) 
Also spreads through flies.
19:
-18- 
 
 
(vi) 
Corona Virus Disease :  It is an acute contagious inflammation of the 
intestines of dogs.  
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS  
 
 
 
(a) 
Lethargy, loss of appetite, vomiting and diarrhea.  
 
 
 
 
 
(b) 
Motions may be loose of yellowish orange colour and may contain 
 
variable amount of mucus or blood. 
 
 
 
(c) 
Secondary bacterial infection increase the severity to an acute 
 
condition. 
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
 
Disease caused by a virus which destroys the wall of the intestine 
 
leading to mal- absorption and diarrhea. 
 
 
 
(vii) 
Rabbies : Disease is fatal and communicable to man if bitten by an affected 
animal.  
 
 
 
SYMPTOMS  
 
 
 
(a) 
In dogs, it is either furious or dumb form. 
 
 
 
(b) 
In furious form, the period of excitement is more. 
 
 
 
(c) 
Animals get paralyzed and die within 05 days. 
 
 
 
(d) 
Excitement manifested by wandering over long distance, hiding in 
 
dark places and excessive friendliness towards their owner ( incase of pet 
 
dogs). 
 
 
 
(e) 
Attacks living or imaginary things without provocation.  
 
 
 
(f) 
Biting of the chain and such other objects.  
 
 
 
CAUSES 
 
 
 
(a) 
Causing agent is a virus present in saliva introduced into the tissues 
 
through wound usually infected by teeth of affected animal.  
  
 
 
(b) 
The infection travels up to the brain through nerves. 
 
 
(viii)  Others 
 
 
 
(a) 
Different types of worms also affect dogs. 
 
 
 
(b) 
Skin problems are another common disease among dogs.
20:
-19- 
 
CHARTER OF DUTIES OF DOG SQUAD STAFF 
 
39. 
Duties of Dog Squad Commander (Sub Inspector) :- 
 
 
(a) 
The Dog Squad Commander shall be responsible for the following :- 
 
 
 
 
(i) 
He will organize his own team properly so that co-ordination  
 
 
is adequately maintained. 
 
 
 
 
(ii) 
He will ensure proper deployment of dog squad in the event  
 
 
of any occurrence/random check. 
 
 
 
 
(iii) 
He shall prepare the search procedure and have it                 
 
 
approved from the concerned authority.  
 
 
 
 
(iv) 
He will be responsible for proper management of Dog  Squad. 
 
 
 
 
(v) 
He will maintain the History Sheet of Dogs. 
 
 
 
(vi) 
He will ensure timely medical check up  of dogs and their       
 
 
treatment whenever required. 
 
 
 
 
(vii) 
He will maintain EVENTS DIARY in which all important          
 
 
events  for  which the dog is  operationally   deployed shall be                  
 
 
recorded / highlighted. 
 
 
 
 
(viii) 
He will be responsible for regular training of dogs. Weekly                  
 
 
 
training programme shall be prepared and training conducted                  
 
 
 
accordingly. A training syllabus is given in Paragraph 14. 
 
 
 
(ix) 
He will closely supervise feeding to dogs, their cooling and  
 
 
heating arrangements, grooming and ensure that all concerned in  
 
 
dog squad  follow daily routing/training programme under his            
 
 
command. 
 
 
 
 
(x) 
He will supervise kennel  hygiene routine.  
 
 
 
 
(xi) 
He will arrange to procure all necessary stores, equipment,    
 
 
ration and training aids from concerned authority and maintain proper 
 
 
record of the same. 
 
 
 
 
(xii) 
He will report to the superior Officer any problem being faced . 
 
 
 
 
(xiii) 
He will be a member of all boards constituted for procurement 
 
 
of   equipment,  training  
aids and  ration  items and  also disposal 
 
 
of condemned stores of dog squads etc.
21:
-20- 
 
 
 
 
(xiv) 
All dog squad personnel like handler, kennel - man will directly 
 
 
be under his command and they will discharge their duties as per  
 
 
his directions. 
 
40. 
DUTIES OF HEAD CONSTABLE/CONSTABLE (DOG HANDLER) :- 
 
(a) 
A dog handler, irrespective of his rank, should be well disciplined and bear 
 
a good moral character. He will perform the following duties :- 
 
 
 
(i) 
He will be responsible to carryout morning to evening routine             
 
 
of his dog. 
 
 
 
(ii) 
Impart  training to the  dog allotted and should bear in   mind that dog 
 
 
is a Govt. property. 
 
 
 
(iii) 
Deliver his duties as and when assigned to the best for his                
 
 
Dog. 
 
 
 
(iv) 
Keep his dog operationally and technically fit for deployment   and  
 
 
also  keep his dog in routine practice for which he should use live samples.  
 
 
 
(v) 
Be responsible for overall welfare of his dog, i.e housing,                  
 
 
feeding, treatment and clothing. 
 
 
 
(vi) 
He 
will 
ensure 
timely 
medical 
check-up, 
immunization,                  
 
 
treatment of dog whenever required and will maintain proper record.                
 
 
 
 
(vii) 
Ensure that all movement of his dog whether indoor or out -                  
 
 
door, on foot is secure with help of a leash. Neck collar and hooks should   
 
 
be checked for any breakage. 
 
 
 
(viii) 
He when asked to be deployed should be in possession of                  
 
 
complete dog equipment and other articles as may be required.                  
 
 
 
 
 
(ix) 
While 
proceeding 
on 
temporary 
duty, 
course, 
leave 
etc                  
 
 
without his dog, he should properly hand over the charge of his dog,                 
 
 
equipment 
and 
should 
brief 
the 
incumbent 
about 
his 
dog’s                  
 
 
habit. In case of sickness, such movement should be restricted and if                  
 
 
unavoidable, proper briefing about the sickness should also be done. 
 
 
 
(x) 
While proceeding without his dog for longer duration, he                  
 
 
should always brief on the due dates of vaccination, heat  (in case of                
 
 
female) de-worming and other important dates. Vet should also be informed 
 
 
in advance.
22:
-21- 
 
 
 
(xi) 
Ensure proper hygiene of kennel, feeding and cleaning of                  
 
 
utensils of his dog. 
 
 
 
(xii) 
Protect his dog from other stray dogs and infected dogs                  
 
 
suffering 
from 
contagious 
diseases 
and 
should 
ensure 
proper                  
 
 
segregation. 
 
 
 
(xiii) 
In case of a stray dog bite, amongst dogs or self, he should                  
 
 
immediately report to Dog Squad I/C or vet and ensure post bite                  
 
 
vaccination as per schedule. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
(xiv) 
He should not handle any material recovered during the                  
 
 
search.  
 
 
 
(xv) 
He will maintain daily log book with regard to the operational                                
 
 
deployment of dog and searches made. 
 
41. 
DUTIES OF KENNELMAN :- 
 
 
 
(i) 
He will ensure proper maintenance of the equipment. 
 
 
 
(ii) 
He is responsible for the maintenance of the Kennel with  
 
 
 
regards to cleanliness and shall ensure necessary comfort of dogs in  
 
 
the Kennel. 
 
 
 
(iii) 
Maintenance of all items provided  in the Kennel for comfort   
 
 
of dogs.  
 
 
 
(iv) 
He will perform any other duty relating to dog squad given to   
 
 
him by his seniors. 
 
 
 
(v) 
He will report immediately to his senior officer about any  
 
 
 
problem with the dogs in Kennel.

43. 
KENNEL DESIGN :- 
 
 
Design of kennel is as per Appendix ‘B’.  
 
44. 
KENNEL MANAGEMENT 
 
 
(i) 
A high standard of kennel management is essential to maintain Dogs at an 
optimum level of health so that they are able to perform their duties efficiently. 
 
 
(ii) 
A tick channel should be constructed, running all round the permanent 
kennels.  This channel should be filled with water. This precaution is necessary to 
prevent the ticks from crawling into the kennels. 
 
 
(iii) 
Each kennel must be supplied with a sleeping board raised a few inches off 
the ground. If dogs are made to sleep on concrete floors, rheumatism and 
accompanying lameness will occurs .The sleeping board must be removable so 
that it can be taken out and scrubbed regularly. 
 
 
45. 
COOLING / HEATING ARRANGEMENT:- 
(i) 
One Air Cooler and one Ceiling Fan will be used per Kennel. 
Replacement/repairing will be done whenever required. Proper maintenance shall 
be ensured by the Kennel-Man. In places where humidity is more than 80%, Air 
Condition (AC) will be utilized. 
 
(ii) 
One heat convector per dog will be used during winter season.
25:
-24- 
 
46. 
KENNEL HYGIENE :- 
 
 
(i) 
Once a year the kennel should be white washed and doors and windows 
freshly painted. 
 
 
(ii) 
Once in a week the kennel floor be washed with Phenyl. Entire kennel 
should be sprayed with insecticides in first fortnight of the month and burned by 
flame lamps in second fortnight. 
 
 
(iii) 
Every month the stool site should be changed. 
 
 
(iv) 
Every month microscopic examination of stool should be done. 
 
 
(v) 
If a dog/pup dies in a kennel, the exterior of the habitat should be 
disinfected with Carbolic Acid and fumigation done by formalin. 
 
HYGIENE CHEMICALS :- 
 
47. 
The following shall be the requirement of hygiene chemicals which shall be made 
available on requirement basis :- 
 
 
(a) 
K. Oil - 50 ltrs per kennel for flaming purpose per month. 
 
 
 
 
 
Or 
 
 
 
One Gas cylinder with flame gun for flaming purpose per month. 
 
 
(b) 
Soap - One bar per dog per month. 
 
 
(c) 
Surf - One packet of 500 grams per kennel per month. 
 
 
(d) 
Phenyl - Two liters per dog per month. 
 
 
(e) 
Odoniles  - Two packets per kennel per month. 
 
 
(f) 
Mosquito repellent spray – One liter per dog per month. 
 
 
(g) 
Spray pump – one per kennel. 
 
 
(h) 
Foot powder – 500 gms per dog per month. 
 
 
(i) 
Soap washing - One packet (150 gms) per handler per month. 
 
48. 
WEDDING OUT OF CONDEMNED DOG /PUPS ;_ 
 
 
(a) 
Dogs after attaining  the age of 10 years are normally recommended for 
condemnation. A Board of Officers comprising of members of airport operator and 
CISF will be nominated to assess the further suitability of the Dogs/Pups. Such 
board of Officers shall consist of a  Veterinary Doctor as a member or his written 
advice may be made a part of proceedings. 
 
 
(b) 
Some defects/deformity such as cataract of eye, laxation of joints, hard of 
hearing, disabilities developed at later part of Dog’s life due to service conditions or 
inheritance make the Dog unfit for further use and in such a case the Board of 
Officers will recommend the Dog whether to put to sleep or auctioned. Postmortem 
of dogs will be mandatorily carried out during death of the dog.
